results.headline: Review: ‘The Whole Truth,’ or a Slimmed-Down Version of It
results.summary_short: Keanu Reeves is a lawyer for a teenager accused of killing his father. Renée Zellweger plays the boy’s mother in this drama that “trundles along.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Whole Truth

results.headline: Review: In ‘Before the Flood,’ Leonardo DiCaprio Sounds the Climate-Change Alarm
results.summary_short: A new documentary chronicles environmental degradation that leads to global warming and suggests steps to reduce it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before the Flood

results.headline: Review: ‘Michael Moore in TrumpLand’ Isn’t About Donald Trump
results.summary_short: The film, which captures a live stage performance by Mr. Moore, is not a rollicking attack on the Republican nominee but a paean to Hillary Clinton.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Michael Moore in TrumpLand

results.headline: Review: In ‘Aquarius,’ a Widow Fights to Keep Her Home
results.summary_short: A free spirit is tangled up in the political forces paralleling modern-day Brazil in this work from Kleber Mendonça Filho.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aquarius

results.headline: Review: In ‘Little Sister,’ an Aspiring Nun With a Love of Goth Visits Her Troubled Family
results.summary_short: The atmosphere can be oppressive in this story of a dysfunctional family, but it’s countered with humor and empathy for each broken character.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little Sister

results.headline: Review: In ‘Miss Hokusai,’ an Apprentice to the Artistic Life
results.summary_short: This extraordinary film is a lively inquiry into the life of the daughter of the 19th-century Japanese painter Katsushika Hokusai.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss Hokusai

results.headline: Review: In ‘Kevin Hart: What Now?,’ a Stadium Brimming With Brash Stand-Up
results.summary_short: The comedian documents his popular 2015 tour in ways surprising and satisfying two-thirds of the time.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kevin Hart: What Now?

results.headline: Review: In ‘Christine,’ Why Did She Pull the Trigger? We Don’t Know
results.summary_short: In this dramatization of a true story, Rebecca Hall is riveting as Christine Chubbuck, a television news reporter who killed herself on the air.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Christine

results.headline: Review: ‘Certain Women’ Are Worlds Unto Themselves
results.summary_short: Kelly Reichardt’s film centers on a collection of women in a small town, and their individual tensions, sorrow and longing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Certain Women

results.headline: Review: ‘Coming Through the Rye’ Tracks Down J.D. Salinger
results.summary_short: The film, written and directed by James Sadwith, is a fictionalized version of Mr. Sadwith’s meeting with J.D. Salinger.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Coming Through the Rye

results.headline: Review: A Crooked Cop Is Caught Between 2 Brutal Masters in ‘Asura: The City of Madness’
results.summary_short: This film offers diversion but not sociological scope. Blood flows freely.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Asura: The City of Madness

results.headline: Review: In ‘The David Dance,’ a Gay Man Sheds His Crippling Self-Doubt
results.summary_short: Troubled by insecurity, the host of a radio show opens his heart to love, and slowly begins to accept himself for who he is.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The David Dance

results.headline: Review: Stranded Migrants Are Easy Marks for a Madman in ‘Desierto’
results.summary_short: Lots of carnage and only a little back story equal a grim movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Desierto

results.headline: Review: ‘Huntwatch’ Chronicles a Hard-Fought Battle to Protect Seals
results.summary_short: This film, one-sided in its approach, offers painful footage of the bludgeoning of pups in charting the decades-old movement against seal hunting.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Huntwatch

results.headline: Review: For ‘Jack Goes Home,’ Cue the Horror Soundtrack
results.summary_short: Rory Culkin plays a magazine editor who returns to his hometown after his father is killed in a car crash, and delves into a past that’s deeply troubled.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jack Goes Home

results.display_title: Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise
results.headline: Review: ‘Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise,’ a Life Well Lived
results.summary_short: Photographs and film footage, as well as interviews with her son and artists who worked with her, add another dimension this documentary of a storied life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise

results.headline: Review: Fireworks in ‘Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang’
results.summary_short: Kevin Macdonald’s documentary follows the Chinese artist as he tries to realize his 20-year dream of creating an incendiary ladder to the skies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sky Ladder

results.headline: Review: ‘Ordinary World’ Puts Billie Joe Armstrong in the Bland Lane
results.summary_short: The Green Day frontman plays an ex-punk rocker who is having trouble accepting a run-of-the-mill existence.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ordinary World

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Accountant,’ Ben Affleck Plays a Savant With a Dark Secret
results.summary_short: The film stars Mr. Affleck as a genius on the autism spectrum whose proficiency with numbers leads him into a shady world.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Accountant

results.headline: Review: ‘Mascots’ Suffers From Mockumentary Fatigue Syndrome
results.summary_short: Christopher Guest’s latest movie is fun, and features many of his usual suspects, but it isn’t as sharp as his previous films.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mascots
